title: onlyAuthenticated
content: @description Guard that checks if the user is authenticated user otherwise redirects to the specified route.

title: onlyGuest
content: @description Guard that checks if the user is not authenticated otherwise redirects to the specified route.

title: Introduction
content: Here you will find a demo of using AWS Cognito with Angular Material components. You can sign up, confirm your account, and log in using the provided forms.

title: Introduction
content: You will find source codes of all examples in GitHub repository.

title: Introduction
content: Pro tip: use the light/dark mode toggle in the top-right corner of the page to see the demo in both light and dark mode.

title: passwordPattern
content: Defines common patterns used for validation in the OmniAuth Core library.

title: passwordPattern
content: These patterns are used for validating passwords and email addresses.

title: AuthCognitoConfig
content: Cognito configuration, add oauth configuration if you want to use oauth providers.

title: AuthComponentConfig
content: Hide message when user is authenticated.

title: OmniAuthService
content: @description The access token is the artifact that allows the client application to access the user's resource.

title: OmniAuthService
content: @description An ID token is an artifact that proves that the user has been authenticated.

title: AuthAwsCognitoService
content: @description The access token is the artifact that allows the client application to access the user's resource.

title: AuthAwsCognitoService
content: @description An ID token is an artifact that proves that the user has been authenticated.

title: SignInProvider
content: @description Icon configuration for the social provider button. Preferably, use SVG icons for better scalability.

title: SignInProvider
content: @description Key used to identify the social provider in the OmniAuthService.

title: SignInProvider
content: @description Label on button, e.g. 'Continue with Google', 'Sign in with Facebook', etc.

title: SignInProvider
content: @description Tooltip text that appears when hovering over the button.

title: What is OmniAuth?
content: OmniAuth is an Angular authentication library designed to seamlessly integrate authentication provider into your Angular applications.

title: What is OmniAuth?
content: Optimized for Modern Angular: Built to leverage Angular's new zoneless architecture for superior performance and efficiencyFlexible Configuration: Wide customization options to match your specific requirements, (including styles, providers)Unified Developer Experience: Clean, intuitive API that remains consistent across all supported authentication providersModular Design: Architected for extensibility with pluggable components that adapt to your project's unique needsZero Setup Friction: Production-ready out of the box with sensible defaults for immediate implementation

title: What is OmniAuth?
content: Perfect for Angular applications of any scale, from simple projects to complex enterprise solutions.

title: What is OmniAuth?
content: OmniAuth is designed to be modular and flexible. The core module provides the main functionality, while additional modules can be added for specific authentication providers or ui components.

title: AuthConfig
content: Automatic bearer authentication, if exist interceptor will be added automatically

title: AuthConfig
content: Passwordless authentication, if true, the user will not be asked for a password when logging in, instead the user will receive a code to log in.

title: AuthConfig
content: The routing configuration, e.g. redirect after login

title: AuthConfig
content: Validate data before sending it to the server (it applies to input fields)

title: JwtPayloadType
content: @description audience(s) that the token is intended for (string or array of strings)

title: JwtPayloadType
content: @description issued at - time at which the token was issued (timestamp in seconds)

title: JwtPayloadType
content: @description issuer of the token (string or URI)

title: JwtPayloadType
content: @description JWT ID - unique identifier for the token (string)

title: JwtPayloadType
content: @description not before - time before which the token must not be accepted for processing (timestamp in seconds)

title: JwtPayloadType
content: @description subject - usually a unique identifier of the user (string or URI)

title: JwtPayloadStandardClaims
content: @description audience(s) that the token is intended for (string or array of strings)

content: @description issued at - time at which the token was issued (timestamp in seconds)

title: JwtPayloadStandardClaims
content: @description issuer of the token (string or URI)

title: JwtPayloadStandardClaims
content: @description JWT ID - unique identifier for the token (string)

title: JwtPayloadStandardClaims
content: @description not before - time before which the token must not be accepted for processing (timestamp in seconds)

title: JwtPayloadStandardClaims
content: @description subject - usually a unique identifier of the user (string or URI)

title: Contribution
content: Contributions are welcome! If you have suggestions for improvements, bug fixes, or new features, please feel free to open an issue or submit a pull request on our GitHub repository

title: Contribution
content: Fork the repository and clone it to your local machine.

title: Contribution
content: Create a new branch for your feature or bug fix.

title: Contribution
content: Make your changes and ensure that the code adheres to the project's coding standards.

title: Contribution
content: Write tests for your changes if applicable.

title: Contribution
content: Commit your changes with a descriptive message using conventional commit style.

title: Contribution
content: Push your changes to your forked repository.

title: Contribution
content: Open a pull request to the main repository, describing your changes and the problem they solve.

title: Contribution
content: Engage in the code review process and make any necessary adjustments based on feedback.

title: Contribution
content: Once approved, your changes will be merged into the main codebase.

title: Contribution
content: Celebrate your contribution to the project!

title: Contribution
content: Ensure you have Node.js installed (version 22 or higher).Install pnpm globally if you haven't already:Install Angular CLI globally if you haven't already:

content: Fork and clone the repositoryNavigate to the project directory and install dependencies:Start the development server with:

title: Configuration
content: Configuration is divided into the following categories:

title: Configuration
content: Core configuration: general configuration of the library.Connector configuration: configure the way how the library communicates with the server.View configuration: configuration of the UI components.

title: Configuration
content: To set up the core configuration, use configureAuth method like in the example below.

title: Configuration
content: See AuthConfig reference to learn more about all configuration options.

title: Configuration
content: Connectors are also set up using provider configuration. Each connector has its own configuration. See the below sections for more information.

title: Configuration
content: To set up the AWS Cognito connector configuration, use configureAuthCognitoConnector method like in the example below.

title: Configuration
content: See AuthCognitoConfig reference to learn more about all configuration options.

title: Configuration
content: To set up the view configuration, use component input properties.

title: Configuration
content: Content configuration is used to control translation and content of the view.

title: Configuration
content: Where content is an object that implements ContentConfig interface. You can extend built-in const (defaultContentEmail).

title: Configuration
content: There are several "slots" that can be used to inject custom content. See the below example.

title: Configuration
content: Here is the list of available slots:

title: Configuration
content: Other configuration options are available within the config input property. See AuthComponentConfig to learn more.

title: Configuration
content: See the Username And Password article for more details

title: Installation
content: All start with installing the core package. You can use either npm, pnpm, or yarn.

title: Installation
content: Then you need to choose and install one of the available connector packages.

title: Installation
content: Connectors are responsible for integrating with different authentication backends. Currently, we support AWS Cognito.

title: Installation
content: Here is the list of available connectors:

title: Installation
content: Finally, you can install one of the available UI packages.

title: Installation
content: UI packages provide pre-built components and styles for authentication-related user interfaces. Currently, we support Material Design.

title: Installation
content: Here is an example of how to configure the OmniAuthModule in your Angular application:

content: This is the default configuration. It uses email and password authentication.

title: Support and Compatibility
content: We maintain support for the latest major version of ngx-omni-auth only. For optimal performance, latest features, and enhanced security, we recommend always using the most current version available.

title: Support and Compatibility
content: Currently supported angular version is 20.x and above.
